message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that works by blocking L-type calcium channels in cardiac and smooth muscle. Option (B) correctly identifies smooth muscle as one of the tissues affected by diltiazem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that primarily blocks L-type calcium channels in cardiac and smooth muscle. Therefore, option (B) is the correct answer. L-type calcium channels in skeletal muscle (option A) play a role in muscle contraction, but are not affected by diltiazem. P-type calcium channels in Purkinje fibers (option C) also play a role in cardiac excitation, but are not affected by diltiazem. N-type calcium channels in the peripheral nervous system (option D) regulate neurotransmitter release, but are not affected by diltiazem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that acts on L-type Ca channels, which are found in both cardiac and smooth muscle cells. Therefore, it would also block depolarization in smooth muscle. The other options are incorrect as they do not involve L-type Ca channels or are in different tissues.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker and mainly blocks the L-type calcium channels in the smooth muscle, leading to vasodilation and decreased blood pressure.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that is commonly used to treat supraventricular tachycardia. It works by blocking L-type calcium channels in cardiac myocytes, which decreases their contractility and slows down the heart rate. However, diltiazem also blocks L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle, which can cause vasodilation and decrease blood pressure. The other options for channels and tissues are not affected by diltiazem’s mechanism of action.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem specifically targets L-type calcium channels in cardiac and smooth muscle, leading to vasodilation and decreased heart rate. The answer is (B). The other options (A, C, and D) are not affected by diltiazem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that primarily targets L-type calcium channels in cardiac and smooth muscle. Option B is the correct answer because it targets L-type calcium channels in smooth muscle, which can cause peripheral vasodilation and also affect arterial pressure. Options A, C, and D are incorrect because they refer to other types of calcium channels that are not affected by diltiazem.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker and works by blocking L-type Ca channels in cardiac muscle and smooth muscle. Among the options, only B is a possible answer.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that works primarily on L-type calcium channels in cardiac and smooth muscle cells. It will not affect P-type calcium channels in Purkinje fibers or N-type calcium channels in the peripheral nervous system. Skeletal muscle cells use a different type of calcium channel, so diltiazem will not have an effect on them either.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Diltiazem is a calcium channel blocker that primarily affects L-type Ca channels in cardiac myocytes, as well as in smooth muscle. Therefore, the correct answer is (B). Diltiazem does not affect L-type Ca channels in skeletal muscle, P-type Ca channels in Purkinje fibers, or N-type Ca channels in the peripheral nervous system.
